lesson.topic: Alkanes, Alkenes, Alcohols, Amines, Aldehydes, Ketones, Acids
lesson.lesson_content:
**Alkanes, Alkenes, Alcohols, Amines, Aldehydes, Ketones, Acids**

**Definition:**
Organic compounds classified based on their functional groups, essential for understanding biochemical processes and drug interactions.

**Key Notions:**
• **Alkanes:** Saturated hydrocarbons with single bonds, stable and non-reactive.
• **Alkenes:** Unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one double bond, more reactive than alkanes.
• **Alcohols:** Contain hydroxyl groups (-OH), important in metabolism and drug design.
• **Amines:** Contain amino groups (-NH2), crucial in protein synthesis and neurotransmission.
• **Aldehydes and Ketones:** Contain carbonyl groups (C=O), aldehydes have at least one hydrogen attached to the carbonyl carbon, ketones do not.
• **Acids:** Contain carboxyl groups (-COOH), essential in biochemical pathways and drug mechanisms.

**Clinical Relevance:**
Understanding these compounds is crucial for pharmacology, metabolism, and biochemical pathways.

**Related Concepts:**
Representation of Organic Molecules, Isomerism, Alkanes, Alkenes, Alcohols, Amines, Aldehydes, Ketones, Acids

options.text: Alkanes have double bonds, Alkenes have single bonds
Alkanes have triple bonds, Alkenes have double bonds
Alkanes have single bonds, Alkenes have double bonds
Alkanes and Alkenes have the same bond types

questions.explanation: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with single bonds, while Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one double bond.

questions.text: In clinical practice, which functional group is most important for drug metabolism?
questions.topic: Alkanes, Alkenes, Alcohols, Amines, Aldehydes, Ketones, Acids
questions.explanation: Alcohols are crucial in drug metabolism due to their hydroxyl groups, which facilitate biochemical reactions.
